statement.text: Lower extremity bypass is a surgical procedure to restore blood flow by connecting an inflow artery to an outflow artery using a conduit (autologous vein or prosthetic graft), bypassing the diseased segment. The great saphenous vein is the preferred conduit for infrainguinal bypass, providing superior patency (70-80% at 5 years) compared to prosthetic grafts (50-60% above-knee, 30-40% below-knee).
statement.formal: Lower Extremity Bypass: Inflow artery (femoral) → Conduit (GSV preferred) → Outflow artery (popliteal/tibial) | Conduit Hierarchy: GSV > Arm vein > PTFE/Dacron | 5-year Patency: Vein 70-80%, Prosthetic AK 50-60%, Prosthetic BK 30-40%

explanation.intuition: Lower extremity bypass is like building a highway bypass around a traffic jam. Instead of trying to fix the blocked artery, you create a new route for blood to flow around the blockage. The 'highway' can be built from the patient's own vein (preferred) or a synthetic tube. The vein works better because the body recognizes it as 'self' and it adapts to arterial pressure - synthetic grafts are more prone to clotting, especially in smaller arteries.
explanation.key_insight: The conduit matters more than the operation itself. A bypass with a good-quality great saphenous vein can last decades. A prosthetic bypass, especially below the knee, may fail within a few years. That's why vein mapping (ultrasound to assess vein quality) before surgery is essential - if the GSV isn't available, arm veins are the next choice before resorting to prosthetic.
explanation.technical_details: Target vessel selection: Choose the most proximal adequate inflow (often common femoral artery) and the best outflow target based on angiography (continuous runoff to foot is ideal). Vein harvest: GSV from ipsilateral or contralateral leg, can be used reversed (valves oriented against flow) or in-situ (valves lysed with valvulotome). Configurations: Fem-pop above-knee, Fem-pop below-knee, Fem-tibial, Sequential (multiple anastomoses). Graft surveillance is critical - detect stenosis before thrombosis allows revision to maintain patency.
common_misconceptions: Prosthetic is equivalent to vein - vein patency is significantly better
Failed bypass = amputation - redo bypass or intervention may salvage limb
All PAD patients need bypass - many can be treated with endovascular techniques
Bypass cures the disease - underlying atherosclerosis continues, surveillance needed

definitions_glossary.conduit: The vessel or graft material connecting inflow to outflow
definitions_glossary.great_saphenous_vein: Superficial leg vein running from ankle to groin
definitions_glossary.patency: Openness of the graft or vessel, typically measured as proportion still open at time X
definitions_glossary.reversed_vein: Vein reversed in orientation so valves allow flow
definitions_glossary.in_situ_bypass: Vein left in place with valves destroyed to allow arterial flow

autologous_vein.arm_veins: Cephalic, basilic - second choice after GSV
autologous_vein.spliced_vein: Combine segments to achieve adequate length

postoperative_surveillance.indication_for_revision: PSV >300 cm/s or PSV ratio >3.5 suggests stenosis

definition.@value: Surgical procedure connecting inflow to outflow artery using conduit to bypass diseased segment

sources.citation: Global Vascular Guidelines on CLTI. J Vasc Surg. 2019;69(6S):3S-125S.

learning_objectives: Describe the principles of lower extremity bypass
Explain the conduit hierarchy and rationale
Understand the importance of graft surveillance
clinical_pearls: Vein is always better than prosthetic below the knee
Map the veins preoperatively with ultrasound
Surveillance prevents graft failure - catch stenosis before thrombosis
Consider endovascular first for TASC A/B lesions
